The time frame is the real issue here. Despite what the government says right now, the chances are not zero and pressure is still going downward. While capital controls are a big step, the longer term outlook for Malaysia is decidedly negative enough that I would put this over 75% if it were 2017 instead of 2016.  Another thing to keep in mind for the people putting "zero" as the forecast: if it were that easy the question wouldn't be here.

Malaysia's economy has weathered recent economic troubles (outside of corruption), relatively well. Capital controls now, after significant devaluation, would be a significant departure from expectations.

08/04/16 - 1%: New governer won't want to be the guy who plunges Malaysia into a new dark age. Also, capital flows are stabilising. The delicate political scenario only hurts sentiment, but investment flows etc. appear to be resilient and more macro-driven.

They are starting to limp a bit, and their governance is rather a mess, but if they do this at all, it probably won't be within this time frame.
Time running out and prior statements that it isn't on the agenda.
It is very improbable because corporations absolutely hate capital controls. Also Malaysia has a stable banking system, low inflation, and foreign investment

Malaysia is currently attempting to increase domestic spending and after seeing China attempt to put in some Capital Control and effects afterwards, it is less likely for Malaysia to try as well. Also, it is a small timeframe and some outside possible supporters see Malaysia as having potential for investments.

Malaysia’s economy might have taken a turn for the worst, but the government is actively trying to right it. This coupled with the fact that foreign investors are looking to invest, and that capital controls usually cripple an economy years after its use, means that there is a low chance Malaysia will commit to economic suicide.

Malaysia’s monetary policy is effective in ensuring adequate levels of liquidity, banking stability and low inflation, said Moody’s Investors Service. The rating agency said the country’s large domestic institutional investor base and net foreign assets also provided ample buffer against financial shocks. Read More : http://www.nst.com.my/news/2016/03/133373/malaysias-monetary-policy-effective-says-moodys Panelists saw a role for both macroprudential as well as capital controls in managing capital flows. Sukudhew Singh, Deputy Governor, Bank Negara Malaysia, saw the need to use the “full spectrum of tools, including capital controls, but policymakers would achieve the best outcomes by working on their own fundamentals.”
http://www.imf.org/external/pubs/ft/survey/so/2016/CAR031516B.htm Bank Negara Malaysia (the central bank) maintains healthy foreign exchange reserves; a well-developed regulatory regime has limited Malaysia's exposure to riskier financial instruments and the global financial crisis.
https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/resources/the-world-factbook/geos/my.html Malaysia has a debt to GDP at 54% ——NOTE-------
Under the circumstances ti seems unlikely
Just a tweak as I compare to other country forecasts.
Could happen, but probably not before October.

Malaysia is still a strong credit at A3/A-/A-.  The currency has been weak relative to its 10 year history (trend would put it around 3.4).  GNP and annual growth rates seem just fine, new high and around 5%.  Consumer and business confidence have been falling but are still not at concern levels.  Central bank balancesheet and reserves provide a lot of flexibility if required.  Capital controls are a sign of serious stress and limited options which I don't see at all here.
http://www.tradingeconomics.com/malaysia/gdp-growth-annual

The previous round of capital controls in 1998 do not seem to show either a positive or negative effect; rather events like the high US interest rates followed by a rate cut seem to be the cause of the regional east Asian turmoil and its resolution. This time, low oil prices as well as the charges of skimming oil revenues, seem to be hitting many oil producers, leading to political and financial issues.
At this time, the chances of capital controls in Malaysia seem low, but this could change.

Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak stated will not impose capital controls to defend the national currency.  An economic crisis bad enough to require it seems unlikely to happen in a few months. http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/business/malaysia-expected-to-save/2465756.html

For countries that have to manage the risks associated with inflow surges or disruptive outflows, a key role needs to be played by macroeconomic policies, as well as by sound financial supervision and regulation, and strong institutions. In certain circumstances, capital flow management measures can be useful. 
http://www.imf.org/external/pubs/ft/survey/so/2012/POL120312A.htm

Malaysian ringgit was free floating between 1995 and 1997.  In 1998 following the Asian financial crisis, the Bank Negara Malaysia pegged the ringgit to the US dollar.  In 2005, Bank Negara ended the peg to USD immediately after China's announcement of end of the renminbi peg to USD.  Currently, the ringgit is free floating.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Malaysian_ringgit Although China has depreciated the renminbi, PBOC has gone to great lengths to keep the renminbi from depreciating too much so that its stock markets are not rattled excessively.  This comes at a huge cost to their foreign exchange reserves. Also:
"A sustained depreciation in the yuan puts pressure on other Asian countries to weaken their currencies and makes commodities denominated in U.S. dollars more expensive for Chinese buyers, which could further depress demand and commodity prices."
http://www.reuters.com/article/us-china-yuan-midpoint-idUSKBN0UL07Z20160107 We see loss of confidence by Chinese workers, more anticipated strikes?  A series of several chemical explosions??  Loss of confidence by Chinese investment "class" as well?
__________________________________________ In 2015, the ringgit fell below its 1998 level versus the USD.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Malaysian_ringgit Is that good or bad for investment in Malaysia?  Should an investor be concerned?  If so, what steps will allay that concern? https://twitter.com/search?q=%23KitaSemuaPenghasut

Capital flight occurs when an economy is tanking and there's better alternatives.  The Malaysian economy is not that much worse off than many.

In the spirit of closing the barn door after the departure of all the equine stock, one can easily imagine some sort of attempted controls after the recent disclosure of massive embezzlement from state funds.  Pointless and ineffective in practice, but maybe symbolic.  Waiting on public reaction from the Malaysian public; they may just be jaded, of course. http://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-35447174

However, Malaysia remains vulnerable to changes in world commodity prices and to a general slowdown in global economic activity.  Malaysia's economy is still largely dependent on exports despite continuing efforts to boost domestic consumption.

As of today the chances of Malaysia impose capital controls before 1 October 2016 are pretty slim. Okay, it's true that a number of emerging markets are taking a risk approach with growing pressure on their currencies and that even China is considering to impose capita controls with its falling capital market. It's also true that Malaysia is facing a weak growth with revenues down due to oil prices and could possibly face a fiscal slippage . Moreover, Malaysia had recently a credit rating downgrade. However, it's important to notice that Prime Minister Najib Razak is, at the very least, sending messages to market agents that he is gonna taking the right measures. An example is that last year budget-deficit reduction was met and measures to boost private spending are taking place. Moreover, US are not elevating its interest. Thus, as a consequence Malaysia ringgit rose for five days already and today is the best performing emerging market currency. On top of that, ten-year sovereign bonds rose, pushing the yield down and there was a rally on brent crude. In a nutshell, things are looking better for Malaysia!! However, it all depends on what will happen to China. So, for the moment I will stick with just 1% and I´m gonna be looking very close as the economic climate develops. http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-01-28/ringgit-gain-leads-emerging-markets-budget-review-in-spotlight
http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-01-28/malaysia-trims-growth-expectations-as-oil-drop-weighs-on-economy
http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-01-28/charting-the-markets-china-falls-again-defying-gains-in-other-emerging-markets
http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-01-27/emerging-stocks-to-currencies-gain-before-fed-concludes-review
http://www.wsj.com/articles/battered-emerging-markets-race-to-stem-outflows-1453410496
http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-01-11/moody-s-cuts-malaysia-credit-rating-outlook-on-weaker-finances
http://www.cbc.ca/news/business/china-capital-controls-foreign-impact-1.3395524
-1% on the 7 week high for the Malaysian ringgit.

Malaysia did impose capital controls in the late 90s and in 2011 the IMF said in certain circumstances capital controls could be warranted.  Therefore, the base rate for this question is higher than it may be for other emerging markets since there is precedent for capital controls being imposed. Also, given the recent emerging market turmoil as a result of China's troubles, it's possible capital controls could be imposed before 1 October, especially if capital continues to flow out of emerging markets, including Malaysia (despite what the government has promised).  Still, it would be a drastic measure borne out of desperation but I'm giving it a higher probability than I would for other countries given the reasons above.

Going to coin flip status based on general debate across emerging markets plus some specific pressures on Malaysia.  http://www.wsj.com/articles/battered-emerging-markets-race-to-stem-outflows-1453410496
http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-01-21/malaysia-cuts-bank-reserve-ratio-keeps-benchmark-rate-steady-ijo3dgir
As long as the currency dosn't plunge, capital controls is very unlikely.

Lowering a bit. Ringgit down some, but not dramatically. This is probably the worst of the combination of low oil prices and turmoil in China, so if this hasn't prompted controls, then nothing else this year is likely to do so (famous last words). My prediction is that oil prices stabilize and start to drift up for most of 2016 and this will reduce downward pressure on ringgit. Plus if Chinese investors really start looking for novel ways to get their capital out, the ringgit might be cheap enough to put a certain gleam in their eyes, at least if they're willing to take some risks. If we get through spring, or oil gets back above $40, with no additional FX drama, I'll go down to 5%.

http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-01-11/moody-s-cuts-malaysia-credit-rating-outlook-on-weaker-finances January 10, 2016.  "Moody’s Investors Service lowered its credit-rating outlook for Malaysia, citing an external environment that has crimped government revenue despite Prime Minister Najib Razak’s efforts to improve the country’s finances.  The ratings company cut the outlook on the A3 sovereign rating to stable from positive, it said on Monday in a statement. The move brings its outlook into line with that of Standard & Poor’s and Fitch Ratings, with all three companies ranking Malaysia at their fourth-lowest investment grades.
. . . . 
"Those environmental changes have also undermined Malaysia’s external position, with large capital outflows, a falling current account surplus, sharp exchange rate depreciation and falling reserves," Moody’s said.
. . ..
The outlook cut from Moody’s comes about six months after Malaysia avoided a credit rating downgrade from Fitch. The ringgit slumped about 19 percent in 2015 -- falling to a 17-year low -- as international investors unloaded Malaysian equities amid domestic political turmoil, falling oil prices and a selloff in emerging-market assets. "It was always difficult for Moody’s to maintain the outlook at positive let alone think about an upgrade given the current environment of low commodity prices and the weak external backdrop," said Euben Paracuelles, an economist at Nomura Holdings Inc. in Singapore. "The fact that they’ve kept it at stable is likely in recognition of the fact that there are actual fiscal reforms that are happening."
~~~~~~~
COMMENT:  I'm feeling pressure to move my forecast in a more positive direction.

http://www.cbc.ca/news/business/china-capital-controls-foreign-impact-1.3395524 According to the above story, China is considering imposing capital controls.  The question is, will other countries in Asia follow suit? How popular in recent decades have capital controls been?
During the Asian crisis of 1990 Malaysia instituted controls. 
According to Bloomberg's Xie, between 1995 and 2010, 37 countries found ways to block the outflow of money.
(How many countries are there?  close to 200?)
Iceland recently lifted controls six years after its banking crisis. 
Cyprus put on controls during its banking meltdown of 2013. 
Ukraine imposed capital controls during its conflict with Russia. 
In 2014 Argentina and Venezuela increased controls. "There are so many ways to move money now, including untraceable bitcoin transactions, that determined individuals can always find a way [around capital controls]", so the question about if capital controls work has become even muddier. "Without truly stringent restrictions that would interfere with trade, even a government determined to stop the flow will only be able to slow it." Just because it may not be effective, doesn't mean it won't be tried.  I'm planning to watch this issue more closely.

adjusting up slightly based on http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-01-11/moody-s-cuts-malaysia-credit-rating-outlook-on-weaker-finances (but on the other hand, for a more upbeat view see http://www.thestar.com.my/business/business-news/2016/01/11/what-is-the-impact-of-a-weak-yuan-on-the-ringgit/)

I"m not changing my prediction, but a lot rides on China's stock market, which is what triggered the capital control issue in the first place.  I"m going to wait and see what happens to China's stocks before making adjustments.

the ringgit & the Malaysian stock market seem to have stabilized since October 2015, but I think it's good to leave some margin for error given known gray swans confronting the world economy & to which Malaysia is exposed
Slightly reducing probability from 13%, as currency outflows and fx reserves have stablized

Ringgit will have continued downward pressure with low oil prices and U.S. interest rates going up, but there isn't any indication of a "disorderly" capital outflow. Capital controls are unpopular, particularly among the countries elite (and presumably well-connected) citizens. They'll avoid them if they can, and so far they can.

The Malaysian Government consistently prioritises its image within Malaysia over its image internationally. It has previously had success implementing capital controls and has a highly interventionalist central bank.
unless Malaysia craters, note 1MDB scandal is the wild card.
Fundamentals weak for Malaysia, not a high conviction case

If the FED hikes tomorrow, everyone and their dog will want to buy USD, which will cause even more outflows out of SEA, including Malaysia. It doesn't help that Malaysia's main export is oil, which is taking a beating at the moment. They will be hurt from a rate hike and a slump in oil prices.
So far away.....Malaysia exposed to commodities, China and rising US interest rates

http://www.thestar.com.my/business/business-news/2015/12/03/modest-slowdown-in-gdp-growth-seen/?style=biz It [ Citi Research] also said that the 1998-style capital controls were not likely.

COMMENT:  On that tidbit of information, I'm lowering my forecast to 11%.

Malaysian economic conditions are poor reflective of a weak commodity business, oversized debt burden and weakening Chinese Yuan having an adverse impact on their currency, flight of capital and equity bear market. Asian economies have experienced similar if not worse financial situation in 1998 and have since implemented control mechanisms, policy reforms and shown remarkable improvement, but post GFC global economy has shifted to the "new normal" lower growth phenomena impacting demand for products particularly resource based.  More importantly, question asked 'capital controls' leaves open the possibility for minor changes and then matter of interpretation. Malaysian government and their central bank have said they will not impose capital controls but that was August 2015 and since then things have gone from bad to worse and our question extends to October 2016 a lot can happen in eleven months.

Peak pessimism and pressure on the ringgit and Malaysian securities seems to have been reached at least in the short run. Informal controls on investment by Government Linked Investment Companies did take place (strong "recommendation" issued by MoF to not take ringgit out of the country) but currently, these are looking to be relaxed as these organization plan for 2016. Peak pessimism on Malaysia Inc. both inside and outside the country seems to have taken place. Tail risks remain--in my mind the core ones are collapse or negative shock in oil prices, China devaluation or debt crisis or severe Malaysian political crisis that collapses confidence in Malaysian sovereign debt / securities. Question needs to be monitored!
http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-11-27/oil-spurs-ringgit-s-best-emerging-market-gain-aided-by-1mdb-sale Recovery in Brent improves Ringgit vs dollar
Decreasing forecast for passage of time.

My first instinct is to go slightly lower than the crowd, since a few of the most dramatic positive predictions seem to be coming from people who disagree with the judges' definition of "capital controls" or who seem to have started with a mindset of "capital controls are very likely" and adjusted downward based on evidence. My starting mindset is more neutral than that.  Still, I'll have time to change my mind if the odds of controls being imposed go down, while I might not have time if they suddenly make a crucial announcement about said imposition on a day that I don't check GJ Open. So I'll start off a bit higher and see whether the situation clears up. Interestingly, some big-name economists think capital controls were a great idea for Malaysia back in the 1990s: https://www.nber.org/papers/w8142 I wonder whether any Malaysian officials have downloaded that one lately
Central Bank and Prime Minister have stated their opposition, low probability case but one cannot be certain
Well, I guess that the judges have decided that the restrictions on expat workers sending funds abroad isn't capital controls.

http://bravenewcoin.com/news/bitcoin-becomes-2015s-best-performing-currency/ "The Malaysian government recently announced strict capital controls to prevent expat workers from sending the Malaysian Ringgit abroad.  To sustain the positive growth of the currency, the government is forcing expat workers to invest a portion of their earnings in a remittance fund called Employees’ Provident Fund (EPF)."   “The government is still determining the sum or percentage of salary that foreign workers need to pay, and when (including special circumstances) the workers can make withdrawals from the fund.”  - Sinchew Daily

The outside view:
How often have capital controls been imposed in Malaysia/SE Asia recently? No.  Despite several moderate downturns (2000, 2008), there have been no capital controls since 1997.  Thus, assume initial odds at 33% (1/3)
Capital controls imposed in the area during downturns -  common in the area.  South Korea and Taiwan have both had some type of capital control.  Raise to 38%
The Inside view
Who can impose capital controls?  What are their views?  Malaysian central bank governors have assured people there will not bne capital flows.  Post Washington consensus, it could piss people off.  But, recent move by international institutions to support small scale controls.  All said, a slight reduction, back to around 33%, pending changes
Does the current situation justify it?  Since August, the fall of the ringit against the dollar appears more managed.  The Malaysian economy is still in growth.  -10% Final: 23%  To reconsider based on new info around exchange rate, the economy and central bank opinion.
No, they will ride out the longer slide away from developing markets without trying to fight it with disasterous mesaures.

I expect another wave of EM turmoil as soon as fed hikes (end of 2015 or early 2016). In a scenario in which USD surges exponentially in a self- fullfilling proficy kinda way (like RUB, BRL) and dollar denominated debt of EM firm start to collaps, I can see that happening.

General consensus of analysis I have read on the subject is that this is a low probability event. However, prolonged or further weakness in oil prices and subsequent currency weakness would make this more likely. My view, based on recent price activity, is that oil prices have largely stabilized at current levels for the foreseeable future.

The question is too broad as the Trans-Pacific trade agreement does not preclude capital controls, it does not support them. Malaysia has Free Trade Agrements with countries that include capital controls. These agreements are grandfathered and controls can be imposed if capital balances fall out of agreed tolerances. The likelihood that they would be imposed by current leaders is minimal as safety valves and other tools are available to maintain balance. The Asian economies are beginning to act regionally and this will encourage more unilateral capital control.
Mahatir isn't not the leader. It will not happen

I'm following forecasts/forecasters I upvoted. 
(I wish I had not forecast on this question and could get out of it because I know zilch and have too much to learn to make up for my ignorance.)

This is only my base estimate or in other words "my outside view". I have calculated this probability only by looking at the how common is capital control in case of financial crisis. As it turn out, in my quick study, there are 4 cases where a country has imposed capital control in past. 1997 Asian financial crisis, Malaysia imposed capital controls andthen Argentina in 2000. In recent years, we have Greece imposing capital control and Iceland.  So my anchor is at 19% probability and I will continue zeroing on Malaysia, its economy and its leaders and corresponsingly change the probability.

This is not 1998.  Despite declining commodity prices, Malaysia is not having an economic crisis.  The country is rather facing a political crisis, which already has an impact on the economy.  The downside to the current situation *may* be limited.
The latest: http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-10-29/malaysia-central-bank-said-to-take-interbank-dollar-deposits Sticking with my forecast for the moment.
Central bank more likely to follow international convention, and realize that capital controls cause more damage.

Capital Controls 'worked' for them last time in 1998 on a couple of fronts.  First, they did not have to borrow from the IMF or subjugate themselves to their programs (which were not improving the situation in 1997 and lead to Anwar's demise).  Second, the outside speculators were no longer able to profit from shorting their currency, while keeping the door open for Direct Foreign Investment.  Finally, the political power to assert internal national controls as opposed to external IMF or investor confidence measures plays towards the popularity argument for parties in or near power.   This move will be used again in times of monetary crises.
I think the government will do what's best for the country

China, Malaysia top trading partner will experience economic growth again, and so will Malaysia
the Ringgit (will not be fixed)
Malaysia Central bank has control of their interest rates to address inflation rates
Malaysian Fiscal policies are in check, employment rates are fair.
There is not need for Capital Control, I do not see a foresee a flight to safety by foreign investors for the next 12 months
Low probability but closely linked to price of oil/palm oil going forward & whether Najib will remain as PM.

While I tend to think that a lot has changed since the Asian currency crisis of the late 90's, it is really impossible to say that it is a 0% probability as some forecasters have stated.  Right now the current leadership in Malaysia is facing a crisis of confidence to to the 1MBD scandal.  This could lead to leadership change in the country, and give leftists a good argument for the 'evils' of the global financial system. However, looking at Argentina, it is clear what can happen when a country loses access to global financial markets.  While these Asian countries are in a better situation as far as debt than 20 years ago, they still need to finance deficits that are getting worse in conjunction with falling commodity revenues. Some good recent research on the situation, including this weekends budget decisions: http://www.cnbc.com/2015/10/23/malaysia-pm-najib-razak-faces-key-test-at-budget.html
http://www.reuters.com/article/2015/10/23/malaysia-budget-highlights-idUSL3N12G1DM20151023
https://www.stratfor.com/image/malaysia-political-uncertainty-hinders-economic-growth
Capital controls have proven ineffective at stemming economic crisis and may actually worsen the situation

I like the rationale by another participant, 2 years of the past 25 have had financial crises and 50% odds on capital controls if a financial crisis occurs (2/25*.5=.04).  I am setting my probability of a financial crisis higher than 8% (2/25) due to the fact that Malaysia's currency reserves have already fallen almost 30% YoY.  
Odds on a financial crisis in Malaysia: 25%
Odds of capital controls in the event of financial crisis: 50%
Odds of capital controls before 10/1/16: (.25*.50)=12.5%

They may have to impose them to avoid bank outflows because of the economic downturn, but there are many adverse consequences from that action for the economy that they will not act unless things get much worse. I don't think they will, only a small chance of that.
Malaysia, Singapore, Venezuela, Russia and Brazil will impose capital controls.

According to the article attached to the question, rising US rates or other factors could trigger further depreciation of the local currency.  Because the Prime Minister has said he will not implement capital controls, I believe it is unlikely he does so unless he believes the economy faces a great crisis.  And still, this may not be the action he takes if a crisis occurs.  I'll say there is a 50% chance of capital controls being implemented in a crisis.  So what are the odds of a crisis?  Since 1990 there have been 2 major economic crises involving Malaysia.  The Asian currency crisis and the global credit crisis. 2/25 = .08 >> .08 x .5 = .04.  Due to the fragility and interconnectedness of the Asian markets, I'll adjust up to .06.  I will not adjust up any further for expectation of rising US rates, because the article states that depreciation has already occurred in anticipation of rising rates.
Najib seems to be weathering the storm for now, fed is still holding off, both making this less likely.

Significant Economic Exposure to China and commodities makes this economy very vulnerable going forward. The weakness in both China and the commodities market, has not yet climaxed. Considering the currency has already suffered immensely up to this point, it is likely, in my opinion, that the government will resort to the typical actions of struggling emerging economies in crisis situations.

I want to change this prediction. The only way this happens is if the Chinese stock market crashes. That won't happen. China is imposing laws and penalties for any brokers who short the market. That alone will keep the market from crashing like we saw in 2008. The fact of the matter is, the United States encourages stock market crashes by allowing market shorts and not prosecuting hedge fund managers who purposely cheat the market. There is a difference between free markets and purposely setting up a market to crash to make billions in Credit default Swaps.  China has also taken many other measures to ensure the stock market doesn't crash. I'm aware it could looking like a pre-1928 market prop, but it's not.  Also, China seems to be willing to start trade negotiations and get on better grounds with Korea and Japan, a la trilateral meetings happening in a couple weeks or so.  Without China's stock market crash, there will be no capital controls imposed by Malaysia.
Capital flows too liquid these days. Elite also need liquidity to keep on sending their wealth out of the country
Not much thrust on the topic since mid-August. Currency is rather steady? Am I reading this wrong?

I'm going against the group think here. Not because the others have bad ideas or lack of reasoning on this, but the wild card of China's stock market. I'm just not a 100% on their stock market rebounding completely. I see a lot of state propping of companies to control the Chinese economic downturn. To be honest, this was the real problem in Malaysia and the only reason capital control was taken off the table was the assurance of a market rebound with China. That is my guess.  The fact that capital control came up so often in conversation tells me that it was highly considered and discussed. What if China's stock market hadn't rebound in July? I think they would have imposed a capital control. I think as long as China's stock market remains relatively stable, Malaysia will not impose a capital control, but if it suddenly plummets, all bets are off.  Will China's stock market crash? Well, lets see what happens in the coming trilateral meetings with Japan and Korea and the development of the U.S. military incursions. ie SE Asia, Australia, and in the Pacific.

Despite the imposition of capital controls during the difficult period that followed the 1997 financial crisis, which (one can argue) were successful, I do not believe that the country will need to resort to it in the near future. While I consider that their current foreign currency reserves are not as extensive as perhaps they should be, the country is considered an attractive foreign investment destination, a great exporter and has adopted many liberal, market-friendly reforms since the troublesome end of the 1990s. The 25% probability is based on a possible ousting of PM Najib's Goverment due to corruption scandals, and the election of a new, less market-friendly successor from UMNO, more similar to former PM Mahathir Mohamed. This could create instability and diminish the market's confidence in the country's economy and the ringgit.

In the 17 years since the imposition of capital control, there are many structural changes in the economy that created an environment where this is far less likely outcome:
1. Malaysia's foreign reserve situation is much stronger than 1997/8 in terms of reserve adequacy to sustain imports or meet short term debts
2. Economy is still growing at a moderate pace and not in free fall
3. Much stronger and independent Central bank with a respected governor who have repeatedly said she believes the weakness in the ringgit is due to perception of the wrongdoings of 1 corporation, albeit sovereign owned, and not systemmic and is much likely to tow the line even if it comes from the Prime Miniter's office
4. The development of Malaysia as a global leader in Islamic Financing over the last two decades, which will be severely compromised should capital control be implemented, and the hard-earned lead will be lost forever
I believe it will happen, but not that quick
I believe it will happen but closer to two years from now.

Both Malaysia's PM and central banker seem to respect free markets somewhat, and both seem satisfied w/ how Malaysia has already been buying back its own currency on the free market, dropping international reserves.  Instilling a peg would only drop reserves even faster, which they seem to recognize.  Also, devaluation pressure on the Ringgit depends on the USD remaining strong, which I don't believe necessarily will be the case, as the Fed moves away from forecasting increased rates.

Malaysia wants to be seen as a player in the global economy - imposing capital controls will severely dent that hard won reputation. Tourism is third largest export and should provide capital should ringgit fall further.
There is an asset deflationary spiral underway which will make capital formation in the undeveloped world so scarce, all the new rules will fall to the old habits over the next year.
The passing of TPP makes this more unlikely for Malaysia.
I am going with the crowd estimate of 15% on this one, slightly increased for gaming,

Denials reveal the anxiety. Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak vowed on Aug. 20 that he would not impose capital controls even though the ringgit has fallen 16 percent against the U.S. dollar this year. The economics behind that assurance is shaky. The exchange rate is back at levels that prompted Najib’s predecessor Mahathir Mohamad to erect barriers to prevent foreign investors from fleeing in 1998.

The need for Malaysia to impose capital controls is still well below crises levels.  The trouble with such statistics, however, is a couple of problems and a crises could quickly develop.  With this question open for a year, virtually anything could happen.  The risk of imposition of capital controls is significant.
US jobs report leading to weaker dollar on anticipated delay of rate increase.  Chinese stimulus to restart some demand.  Reports that the lower dollar is pulling cash back to the ringget.
